Learning From Compressed Observations

Maxim Raginsky Beckman Institute and University of Illinois
405 N Mathews Ave, Urbana, IL 61801
maxim@uiuc.edu
Abstract

The problem of statistical learning is to construct a predictor of a random variable Yğ‘ŒY as a function of a related random variable Xğ‘‹X on the basis of an i.i.d.Â training sample from the joint distribution of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y). Allowable predictors are drawn from some specified class, and the goal is to approach asymptotically the performance (expected loss) of the best predictor in the class. We consider the setting in which one has perfect observation of the Xğ‘‹X-part of the sample, while the Yğ‘ŒY-part has to be communicated at some finite bit rate. The encoding of the Yğ‘ŒY-values is allowed to depend on the Xğ‘‹X-values. Under suitable regularity conditions on the admissible predictors, the underlying family of probability distributions and the loss function, we give an information-theoretic characterization of achievable predictor performance in terms of conditional distortion-rate functions. The ideas are illustrated on the example of nonparametric regression in Gaussian noise.

I Introduction and problem statement

Let Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY be jointly distributed random variables, where Xğ‘‹X takes values in an input space ğ’³ğ’³{\cal X} and Yğ‘ŒY takes values in an output space ğ’´ğ’´{\cal Y}. The problem of statistical learning is about constructing an accurate predictor of Yğ‘ŒY as a function of Xğ‘‹X on the basis of some number of independent copies of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y), often with very little or no prior knowledge of the underlying distribution. A very general decision-theoretic framework for learning was proposed by Haussler [1]. In a slightly simplified form it goes as follows. Let ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P} be a family of probability distributions on ğ’µ=ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’µğ’³ğ’´{\cal Z}={\cal X}\times{\cal Y}. Each member Pğ‘ƒP of ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P} represents a possible relationship between Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY. For any fâˆˆâ„±ğ‘“â„±f\in{\cal F} and any Pâˆˆğ’«ğ‘ƒğ’«P\in{\cal P} we have the expected loss (or risk)

It is general enough to cover such problems as classification, regression and density estimation.

for every Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 and every Pâˆˆğ’«ğ‘ƒğ’«P\in{\cal P}. (See, e.g., Vidyasagar [2].)

This formulation assumes that the training data are available to the learner with arbitrary precision. This assumption may not always hold, however. For example, the location at which the training data are gathered may be geographically separated from the location where the learning actually takes place. Therefore, the training data may have to be communicated to the learner over a channel of finite capacity. In that case, the learner will see only a quantized version of the training data, and must be able to cope with this to the extent allowed by the fundamental limitations imposed by rate-distortion theory. In this paper, we consider a special case of such learning under rate constraints, when the learner has perfect observation of the input part Xn=(X1,â€¦,Xn)superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n}=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) of the training sequence, while the output part Yn=(Y1,â€¦,Yn)superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) has to be communicated via a noiseless digital channel whose capacity is Rğ‘…R bits per sample. This situation, shown in FigureÂ 1, may arise, for example, in remote sensing, where the Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}â€™s are the locations of the sensors and the Yisubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–Y_{i}â€™s are the measurements of the sensors having the form f0â€‹(Xi)+Zisubscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–f_{0}(X_{i})+Z_{i}, where f0:ğ’³â†’[0,1]:subscriptğ‘“0â†’ğ’³01f_{0}:{\cal X}\rightarrow[0,1] is some unknown function and the Zisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–Z_{i}â€™s are i.i.d. zero-mean Gaussian random variables with variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. Assuming that the sensors are dispersed at random over some bounded spatial region ğ’³ğ’³{\cal X} and the location of each sensor is known following its deployment, the task of the sensor array is to deliver, over a rate-limited channel, an approximation Y^nsuperscript^ğ‘Œğ‘›\widehat{Y}^{n} of the measurement vector Yn=(Y1,â€¦,Yn)superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) to some central location, where the vector Xnsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n} of the sensor locations and the compressed version Y^nsuperscript^ğ‘Œğ‘›\widehat{Y}^{n} of the sensor measurements will be fed into a learner that will approximate f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} by some function f^nâ€‹(Xn,Y^n,â‹…)subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscript^ğ‘Œğ‘›â‹…\widehat{f}_{n}(X^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n},\cdot) from a given hypothesis class â„±â„±{\cal F}.

In this paper, we establish information-theoretic upper bounds on the achievable generalization error in this setting. In particular, we relate the problem of agnostic learning under (partial) rate constraints to conditional rate-distortion theory [3, SectionÂ 6.1], [4], [5, AppendixÂ A], which is concerned with lossy source coding in the presence of side information both at the encoder and at the decoder. In the set-up shown in FigureÂ 1, the input part Xn=(X1,â€¦,Xn)superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n}=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) of the training sequence, which is available both to the encoder and to the decoder (hence to the learner), plays the role of the side information, while the output part Yn=(Y1,â€¦,Yn)superscriptğ‘Œğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘›Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) is to be coded using a lossy source code operating at the rate of Rğ‘…R bits per symbol. Furthermore, because the distribution of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y) is known only to be a member of some family ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P}, the lossy codes must be robust in the presence of this uncertainty.

Let us formally state the problem. Let ğ’«,â„±,â„“ğ’«â„±â„“{\cal P},{\cal F},\ell be given. I-A Related work

Previously, the problem of statistical estimation from compressed data was considered by Zhang and Berger [6], Ahlswede and Burnashev [7] and Han and Amari [8] from the viewpoint of multiterminal information theory. In these papers, the underlying family of distributions of (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y) is parametric, i.e., of the form ğ’«={PÎ¸}Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğ’«subscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğœƒÎ˜{\cal P}=\{P_{\theta}\}_{\theta\in\Theta}, where Î˜Î˜\Theta is a subset of â„ksuperscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbb{R}^{k} for some finite kğ‘˜k, and one wishes to estimate the â€œtrueâ€ parameter Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*}. The i.i.d.Â observations {(Xi,Yi)}i=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–1\{(X_{i},Y_{i})\}^{n}_{i=1} are drawn from PÎ¸âˆ—subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœƒP_{\theta^{*}}, and the input part Xnsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n} is communicated to the statistician at some rate R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}, while the output part Ynsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘›Y^{n} is communicated at some rate R2subscriptğ‘…2R_{2}. The present work generalizes to the nonparametric setting the case considered by Ahlswede and Burnashev [7], namely when R1=âˆsubscriptğ‘…1R_{1}=\infty. To the best of the authorâ€™s knowledge, this paper is the first to consider the problem of nonparametric learning from compressed observations with side information.

II Assumptions

We begin by stating some basic assumptions on â„±â„±{\cal F}, ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P} and â„“â„“\ell. Additional assumptions will be listed in the sequel as needed.

The input space ğ’³ğ’³{\cal X} is taken to be a measurable subset of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, while the output space is either a finite set (as in classification) or the set of reals â„â„\mathbb{R} (as in regression or function estimation). We assume throughout that the family ğ’«ğ’«{\cal P} of distributions on ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´{\cal X}\times{\cal Y} is such that the mutual information Iâ€‹(X;Y)<âˆğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒI(X;Y)<\infty for every Pâˆˆğ’«ğ‘ƒğ’«P\in{\cal P}. All information-theoretic quantities will be in bits, unless specified otherwise.

We assume that there exists a learning algorithm which generalizes optimally in the absence of any rate constraints. V Discussion and future work

We have derived information-theoretic bounds on the achievable generalization error in learning from compressed data (with side information). There is a close relationship between this problem and the theory of robust lossy source coding with side information at the encoder and the decoder. A major difference between this setting and the usual setting of learning theory is that the techniques are no longer distribution-free because restrictions must be placed on the underlying family of distributions in order to guarantee the existence of a suitable source code. The theory was applied to the problem of nonparametric regression in Gaussian noise, where we have shown that the penalty incurred for using compressed observations decays exponentially with the rate.

We have proved TheoremsÂ III.1 and III.3 by adopting ERM as our learning algorithm and optimizing the source code to deliver the best possible reconstruction of the training data. In effect, this imposes a separation structure between learning and source coding. While this â€œmodularâ€ approach is simplistic (clearly, additional performance gains could be attained by designing the encoder, the decoder and the learner jointly), it may be justified in such applications as remote sensing. For instance, if the source code and the learner were designed jointly, then any change made to the hypothesis class (say, if we decided to replace the currently used hypothesis class with another based on tracking the prior performance of the network) might call for a complete redesign of the source code and the sensor network, which may be a costly step. With the modular approach, no such redesign is necessary: one merely makes the necessary adjustments in the learning algorithm, while the sensor network continues to operate as before.

Let us close by sketching some directions for future work. First of all, it would be of interest to derive information-theoretic lower bounds on the generalization performance of rate-constrained learning algorithms. In particular, just as Ahlswede and Burnashev had done in the parametric case [7], we could study the asymptotics of the ninimax excess risk

Î´nâ€‹(R)=â–³inf(en,dn,f^n)supPâˆˆğ’«[ğ”¼â¡Lâ€‹(f^n,P)âˆ’Lâˆ—â€‹(â„±,P)],superscriptâ–³subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›ğ‘…subscriptinfimumsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptsupremumğ‘ƒğ’«delimited-[]ğ”¼ğ¿subscript^ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ¿â„±ğ‘ƒ\delta_{n}(R)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\inf_{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})}\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}\Big{[}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)-L^{*}({\cal F},P)\Big{]},

where the infimum is over all encoders, decoders and learners operating on a length-nğ‘›n training sequence at rate Rğ‘…R. Secondly, we could dispense with the assumption that the learner has perfect observation of the input part of the training sample, in analogy to the situation dealt with by Zhang and Berger [6]. Finally, keeping in mind the motivating example of sensor networks, it would be useful to replace the block coding approach used here with an efficient distributed scheme.
